Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2013 06:23PM Spoomsister wrote: Today I went to the hair salon and got a pretty cut with highlights. Doesn't sound like much, but it helped me feel better and less anxious. First Dr. visit in the morning. Fingers crossed it's nothing to worry about. :o)
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2013 01:34PM Spoomsister wrote: As I was typing that irregular was good I started thinking "wait, I'm pretty sure I have that backwards"! Lol! Thanks for the link DiveCat! It explains it all really well. Keeping my fingers crossed for the bx.
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2013 06:37AM Spoomsister wrote: Hello ladies! Hope you are all enjoying your weekend. It's raining here, but I love the rain, so I am happy. I got a call from the cancer center yesterday asking if I wanted to participate in a new research study by using a new type of digital mammography to detect BC in women with dense breast tissue. It is supposed to help differentiate adipose (fat) tissue, lipids, and water in the breast, which in turn will show cyst vs mass, pick up smaller masses, give them better measurements of a mass with ill defined margins like mine, etc. Of course I agreed. Anything to help them find improved BC detection is fine with me. Well, almost anything. They are going to do the additional mammo right before my biopsy Monday. It should help them see if there are any other additional areas of concern that were hidden by high density on the regular digital mammo. I'm kind of excited about this. Plus, they are giving me $50 for doing it. Maybe I'll take my husband out to dinner after the biopsy is done. :o)
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2013 02:58AM Spoomsister wrote: I can't sleep. I've been up since 4 o'clock this morning, tossing and turning for 45 minutes before I decided to just get up and have my morning cup of coffee. We are leaving at 9:30 to head up to the cancer center for three different appointments today, ending with the biopsy. I'm so nervous. I wish the biopsy was first so I could get that over with. I know it's not that big of a deal. I assist in all types of biopsies ( EXCEPT breast ironically) everyday and I know the patients don't feel any pain with the exception of how we have to have them lay on the table. We have a pathologist with their microscope and stains in the room who immediately look at the cells to see if it is malignant or not, but I don't think they do the same for breast biopsies at the place I am going. The next couple of days are going to be so hard waiting for those results. Does anyone have a time machine I can borrow?
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2013 06:28AM - edited Nov 5, 2013 08:58AM by Spoomsister Thanks Susan and Bliss. My "team" is made up of wonderful doctors and nurses. I'm really happy with them and trust them with my care. I'm alright with them taking this thing out, malignant or not. I don't really like it, and although my breast may have become attached to it, I sure haven't! One little thing I forgot to mention, when the Radiologist was pushing on my breast really hard to advance the introducer needle I told him "This is the worst foreplay I have ever had, just so you know." The other Radiologist and the Ultrasound Tech thought it was really funny, but the Rad doing the biopsy was less than amused. Typical doc. Lol!
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2014 03:19AM Spoomsister wrote: Genny, If they can do your biopsy Wednesday you should be healed enough by the 19th to enjoy your vacation.  I was pretty sore for a few days after mine, and you aren't supposed to get the site wet for a couple days, but thats it.  It does kind of sound pretty suspicious for cancer though... Please keep me updated and try to stay positive.  Enjoy your vacation as much as possible, though I am sure this will be in the back of your mind constantly.  One thing you should be prepared for, if the biopsy is done Wednesday you may find out if it is positive or negative by Friday.  PLEASE keep us updated on this thread.  I will keep you in my prayers. Cgood and Juneping thanks for liking my FB page!  :)  I blog about this whole journey and post updates on there frequently.  Chemo #6 for me today!  Whoo hoo! Mama, I don't have IDC, but I know it's fairly common.  I think there is a forum on here for those diagnosed with IDC.  They may be able to help answer some of your questions.  I hope you are doing well.  The beginning is such a whirlwind of emotions and learning like you said.  I will keep you in my prayers as well.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2014 07:53AM Spoomsister wrote: Genny,  That's a really tough decision to make.  I can tell you the main reason I am having the bilateral mastectomy done is because the cancer is Triple Negative and Grade III.  All cancers of course can spread, so that would have to be a personal choice for you, but I would definately ask your oncologist more questions.  I would have rather had a lumpectomy, but I also don't EVER want to do this again.  I know that probably doesn't really help, but I figured I would still give my 2 cents.

Starting to have headaches from being a bit stressed. Trying to relax and focus on daily activities, but it is always on my mind.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2013 09:08AM Spoomsister wrote: RollerDerby, thanks so much for taking the time to type all of that out. Some of it kinda sucks to hear, but I'd rather know the reality than be full of expectations that are not realistic. I am actually going to Moffitt for my care. I LOVE that place! Everyone is so nice, with such great attitudes! I'll have to look into the direct-to-implant option. I wonder if any of the surgeons at Moffitt do that. I'm going to look into the genetic testing. I have two daughters, so I want to know if their risk of BC is increased as well. I don't have any family history of BC, like you, but I think it's important to find out regardless. Thanks again for your post. Now I have even more questions for my doc on Tuesday. :)
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Spoomsister wrote: 3-4 weeks ago my husband and I were getting ready for bed. He said something sarcastically funny, so I turned to him and made a muscle man pose, showing off my not so strong muscles as a joke. He made a remark about how my left breast looked a little strange, so I turned to check it out in the mirror. I had to do "the pose" again to see how the breast was pulling in under the nipple. I blew this off as getting older (I'm 37), cellulite, and needing to work out. Fast forward to last week... I was getting ready for work Friday morning, and as I raised my left arm up over my head there it was, pulling in the skin on the bottom of my left breast. I wasn't tightening my muscles, just raising my arm. I immediately was alarmed. It is a horizontal line, about 1 1/2" across, with some dimpling around it. I never knew until Friday that this "tethering" was even a sign of breast cancer. I made an appointment with my PCP for this coming Friday at 10:30 in the morning. I'm not as freaked out now as I was this past weekend, I'm starting to come to terms with the possibility of being diagnosed with breast cancer (just in case) and I will find a way to make this experience as positive as possible. I'm wondering if any other women on this forum have had a similar experience and if so, what was the actual cause of the tethering. A little history, I had a partial hysterectomy at 24 (endometriosis and, have 3 children, 2 of which I breast fed 6-7 months, my youngest is 13, I'm only slightly overweight (10 lbs). My breast are natural, and very dense. One of my best assets, or so I thought. Lol. I was a smoker for nearly 20 years, but I quit 3 years ago. Yay! No other medical history. Also, what should I expect at my visit with my doctor? Dimpling found September, 2013, Mass found on Mammo and Ultrasound, BIRAD 5 on 10-29-13, Biopsy on 11-4-13 Dx 11/6/2013, IDC, 4cm, Stage II, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 12/2/2013 AC Chemotherapy 1/27/2014 Taxol (paclitaxel) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2013 08:23AM Spoomsister wrote: Biopsy is tomorrow. I keep going back and forth between dismissing everything, thinking there is no way I have cancer, to I'm 99% sure I have BC. Then I go from thinking they will just cut it out and I will go on my merry way to "what if it's stage 4?!?", to maybe I'll get new boobs out of this, though I really like the ones I've got. I'm sure all this is pretty normal, but I'm logging my journey and feelings for myself and others. Today we are going to the Seafood Festival and it is absolutely beautiful out. Should be a fun day and yet another great distraction. :o)
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2013 02:43PM Spoomsister wrote: I am home from the biopsy. The biopsy itself wasn't nearly as bad as I expected. Just a little stinging in the beginning while they were numbing up the breast tissue. The biggest problem was the radiologist trying to get the needle to advance into the mass. Mother *&&^%! He ended up having to use both hands to really push the needle into the mass itself. Ultrasound tech and other radiologist both said the mass was very hard, so I would be extremely sore and have a lot of bruising. They were not kidding. My whole breast feels like it is on fire. Bleh! I did meet with the breast surgeon before the biopsy. She was wonderful. Excellent bedside manner, answered all of our questions, etc. She said she feels like we likely caught it early, if it is indeed malignant, but she wants me to get an MRI done to see if we are missing anything on the mammo with my breasts being so dense. She also said that with the mass size, irregular borders, the spiculated appearance, etc. that we will be doing surgery to remove it even if the biopsy results come back negative. Not quite sure why, but I will ask her next time I see her. Should get my results Wednesday or Thursday. That's all for now. :o) Thanks again to everyone for all of your support. You guys are amazing!
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Maybe you will help save other peoples lives. :0) I'm really, really hoping I can do that, but I'm coming to terms with being okay if it's not an option. Chipmunk, my lucky number is 13, so I'm sure it's all good. Best of luck to you guys!
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2014 02:29AM Spoomsister wrote: I have missed a lot of stuff on here recently!  I'm so sorry guys.  My new chemo treatments are pretty rough, and I have been slacking on these boards.  I read through all of the posts.  It's unfortunate that all have to be here, but it is such a wonderful place to meet amazing women (and men apparently, thank you for your wonderful post rockforlight).  I am doing chemo before surgery, someone had asked that earlier.  It's fairly common to do, especially for those with aggressive cancers.  Sounds backwards, I know, but it was explained to me like this:  The cancer is really aggressive and can spread quickly.  Even if your initial scans come back clear, that just means that cancer hasn't formed into anything large enough yet to be detected.  There can still be micro cancer cells floating around in your system, especially with invasive cancers.  If the chemo is done first, the effects of chemo on the cancer in the breast can be monitored to make sure the chemo is working.  If the mass is removed first, then there isn't a way to gauge how effective the chemo is on your cancer.  Apparently, there isn't a difference in survival rates on having chemo before or after surgery.  Oh, one big thing I noticed.  I told someone I didn't have IDC for some odd reason.  I must have been right out of chemo with some severe chemo brain.  I DO have IDC.  I think I must have said that because I usually refer to my cancer as Triple Negative, and leave out the IDC part.  Mainly because that's what my new cancer friends who also have TN Cancer refer to it as.  I wish all of you the best of luck on here.  Hopefully everyone is doing well.  I will do my best to be more active on this board and answer any questions you guys might have.  :o) KJ (AKA Spoomsister)

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2013 08:45AM Spoomsister wrote: You guys are all so awesome on this site! So glad I found this forum. It keeps my mind at ease, knowing there are so many other women that have gone though this process and made it out stronger, more beautiful women. Mama-Ski, I don't know really if it is considered tethering, puckering, or dimpling, or if those are all used interchangeably. When I tense my breast muscles part of my breast sucks in on it self, about the size of a half- dollar, with some lines running horizontally on each side that somewhat resemble stretch marks. I thought at first it was due to getting older, (I'm 37), but then when I raised my arm over my head I could still see it and I wasn't tightening my muscles at all. Did some research, freaked out big time, and found this site. I have an appointment at the womens cancer center Tuesday and should know if it is BC or something B9 causing this. Off topic.... Where is your hubby deploying to? Hopefully it is a 4 month assignment and not something longer. :o( Tonight we are going to an uninhabited island with a bunch of friends for a bonfire beach party. So excited for that! My husband is loading the firewood on our boat as I type this. Definately a wonderful distraction from all this.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2013 12:39PM Spoomsister wrote: Soooooo, I just got home from my doctor visit. Mammo and Ultrasound both found a mass behind the dimpled area. It's small, 2cm is what he said, tech measured 4cm though. Biopsy scheduled for Monday. Tried to go to work, but I broke down and lost it as soon as my coworker asked how it went. Went home, stopped by CVS to pick up my script for Xanax, then picked up a 6 pack of Blue Moon. Bleh. I'm anxious to get the radiologist official report. He did come in the ultrasound room to look for himself, told me the BIRAD 5 - Highly suspicious of malignancy, BUT he didn't see anything on the mammo in my right breast, so that is good. I'll type more soon. I'm gonna go have a beer. ;o)
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

I am the type that wants to know everything, but until I know what I'm dealing with that will be difficult. I'm sure I'll have a ton of questions as this goes on. Right now I'm most worried about the biopsy hurting, but I know that miniscule compared to other things. Lol!

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2013 07:34PM Spoomsister wrote: It has been SUCH a long day. I wasn't myself this morning, knowing that I could be getting my results at any moment kept me in such a somber mood. Tim (my husband) finally made me get out of the house and go with him out to the island. It was a beautiful day, with only one other boat on the island, and we were in our own personal paradise. We were searching for shark teeth along the shore when my phone rang. It was Raye, my NP. "Unfortunately I have bad news. The biopsy came back positive for cancer." I asked her if she knew what type, she said what I expected, it's IDC, Invasive Ductal Carcinoma. MRI is scheduled for Monday to see if it has spread, and I am meeting with a doc on Tuesday to get more info from pathology on treatments, etc. I am still in shock a little. I can't believe I have cancer. We will get through this, but it is still so shocking to hear. Love you all. :o)
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2013 04:36PM Spoomsister wrote: So, I got my results. Not at all what I was expecting to hear. Cancer is grade III, highly aggressive, stage II (cancer measured 4cm), and it's triple negative. Starting chemo soon. Have CT scan tomorrow to check for organ mets, and bone scan to check for bone mets, then port placement, chemo (paclitaxel) every 2 weeks for 4 months, then bilateral mastectomy. I'm so sad today, but I know I will be better once this sinks in.
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2013 04:17AM Spoomsister wrote: Sorry I haven't posted any replies for a bit to all who have posted here. I've been reading them, and they make my heart smile every time, I've just been trying to process all of this and comprehend everything that lies ahead. Doctors appointments have become numerous, really cutting into my work schedule (and my paycheck), and so many old friends and family have been contacting me offering their well wishes and prayers. My Cat Scan came back clear, so that is some good news. Bone scan revealed a "hot spot" on one of my ribs (5th rib, posterior, right side), should find out what we are going to do about that on Monday. I had a power port placed yesterday, and that went very smoothly, though the pain after the meds wore off was quite a bit more than I expected. Seems to be a little better today though. I have family coming down for a surprise trip, they should be arriving tomorrow, so I need to get the house in order just a tad. Good thing I have teenagers here to help. :) Hope you are all doing well. Thanks again for the encouragement and understanding you have all given.
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2014 04:40AM Spoomsister wrote: Genny, I'm so sorry to hear your results. It's all so much to take in right before your vacation too.  It sounds like you have found a great new friend in the administrator at work.  She will be more helpful throughout this journey than you may realize at the moment.  Your doctor sounds pretty amazing also.  You can do this.  It won't be easy, but you will prevail. :0)
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Spoomsister wrote: 3-4 weeks ago my husband and I were getting ready for bed. He said something sarcastically funny, so I turned to him and made a muscle man pose, showing off my not so strong muscles as a joke. He made a remark about how my left breast looked a little strange, so I turned to check it out in the mirror. I had to do "the pose" again to see how the breast was pulling in under the nipple. I blew this off as getting older (I'm 37), cellulite, and needing to work out. Fast forward to last week... I was getting ready for work Friday morning, and as I raised my left arm up over my head there it was, pulling in the skin on the bottom of my left breast. I wasn't tightening my muscles, just raising my arm. I immediately was alarmed. It is a horizontal line, about 1 1/2" across, with some dimpling around it. I never knew until Friday that this "tethering" was even a sign of breast cancer. I made an appointment with my PCP for this coming Friday at 10:30 in the morning. I'm not as freaked out now as I was this past weekend, I'm starting to come to terms with the possibility of being diagnosed with breast cancer (just in case) and I will find a way to make this experience as positive as possible. I'm wondering if any other women on this forum have had a similar experience and if so, what was the actual cause of the tethering. A little history, I had a partial hysterectomy at 24 (endometriosis and, have 3 children, 2 of which I breast fed 6-7 months, my youngest is 13, I'm only slightly overweight (10 lbs). My breast are natural, and very dense. One of my best assets, or so I thought. Lol. I was a smoker for nearly 20 years, but I quit 3 years ago. Yay! No other medical history. Also, what should I expect at my visit with my doctor? Dimpling found September, 2013, Mass found on Mammo and Ultrasound, BIRAD 5 on 10-29-13, Biopsy on 11-4-13 Dx 11/6/2013, IDC, 4cm, Stage II, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 12/2/2013 AC Chemotherapy 1/27/2014 Taxol (paclitaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2013 08:03PM Spoomsister wrote: It's amazing how much just doing something for ourselves, even if it's something small, can make a world of difference. Thanks for the good luck! I'll post of course what I find out. I'm somewhat using this board as personal therapy and a way to log this journey, no matter where it takes my family and I. :o) Best wishes to all the other women on this board. It has been a mind saver for me.

Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2013 01:17PM - edited Nov 4, 2013 02:48AM by Spoomsister SheChirple, I really have started to notice how beautiful everything is, things that I would have overlooked before. I'm actually really enjoying that part of this, and it's not in a sad, melancholy way either. It's a happy, sunny, appreciative attitude that I like. :o) The uninhabited island experience was wonderful, yet not new to me. We met some great new friends out there too. Bliss, thank you for the hugs and encouragement! Everyone here is so supportive, even though you all have your own struggles. This is such an amazing group. Science, don't worry, I'm sure I'll be here crying and screaming from time to time. I've just happened to only be online during my "up" moods so far. It's coming, just give me time. But thanks in advance for letting me know that it is okay to do should I need to. ;o)
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2013 06:28AM Spoomsister wrote: Thanks guys. The support here is so wonderful! Today I am kinda freaking out a little bit now that it is starting to set in and the shock is wearing off. I do have a couple of questions. Is it possible to get a mastectomy and not do radiation or chemo? Also, is it possible to have reconstructive surgery the same day as the mastectomy if you stay the same cup size? I just want these ones gone. Scoop 'em out and fill them back up with sh*t that doesn't try to kill me. :)

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2013 08:54PM Spoomsister wrote: Chipmunk, So sorry to hear about your diagnosis. How are you doing? I keep having mood swings somewhat, where I go from it's fine, just a simple surgery, to holy cow this is a huge deal! It's crazy, but I think I'll feel better next Tuesday when I find out the rest of the info and get a plan in place. Feel free to message me any time too. Be can whine, cry, and laugh with each other through this crazy process.

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2014 05:08AM Spoomsister wrote: Hi Mama-Ski!!!!  It's been quite awhile!  How are you doing?  I''m doing well on my non-chemo weeks, but the weeks I have chemo are pretty tough.  I'm in my downhill phase now though, only 6 more weeks then I have surgery.  Are you on FB?  I have a FB page that I post all my updates on.  Hit me up on there if you want and we can keep in touch.  :)  Oh, here is the link....  KJ's Triple Negative Fight I really hope everything is going well with you.  Hugs.
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2014 06:50AM Spoomsister wrote: Hi ladies!  Genny, how are you doing with the bone pain?  I took Claritan and Mobic (prescription), but it was still awful for me for about 3-4 days.  It was the most difficult part of chemo.  Slappy, I'm glad you told them you could take an earlier appointment.  Hopefully one will open up.  That is SO long to wait for a biopsy!!!!  Keep us updated of course.  I finished Chemo on Tuesday!  Yay! It honestly went by quicker than I imagined, but that's easy to say now that it's over.  4 months long, but it's done.  Having an MRI April 8th to see if the chemo did it's job.  Fingers crossed!  My surgery date is April 16th.  I can't believe it's a 12 hour surgery with a 5 day hospital stay.  That part scares me a bit.  Hope you all had a good weekend.  It was beautiful here.
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2014 06:21AM - edited Mar 29, 2014 06:24AM by Spoomsister Hi ladies!  Sorry I have been MIA again for a bit.  I'm trying to get everything ready for surgery while battling the fatigue from the last chemo treatment.  I've been struggling emotionaly while trying to come to terms with loosing my breasts in a couple weeks.  It seems silly, after everything they have put me through, but they are a part of me that I don't particularly want gone.  I wrote another blog about it this morning, if you want to read it.  It's a bit graphic, but I try to be honest in my writings.  Warning:  It includes a picture of a woman who had DIEP Flap Reconstruction recently.  It isn't too bad, but it does show her new "foobs".  Here is the link : Why Getting Breast Reconstruction Is NOT the Same As Getting A "Boob Job" Slappy, I'm happy to hear you are finally getting the biopsy done.  I will pray for benign results for you!  Genny, I love the pictures of Nora and your dogs!  I have an Aussie Shep named Roxie who is my therapy dog, even though she isn't certified.  :)  Animals have such a keen sense of emotion, it's crazy how loveable they become when we are "sick".  Hope chemo is going well for all of you who are at that point.  It's a rough road, but it's honestly over fairly quickly.  I thought it would never end, then all of a sudden I was done.  That was a great feeling!  Hope you all have a beautiful weekend!!!
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2014 04:20AM Spoomsister wrote: Slappy, I'm glad the biopsy is over for you and you are doing well.  Waiting until Monday is going to be hard.  It's so difficult just sitting there waiting to find out if you have cancer or not.  Try and keep yourself busy this weekend, do anything that will keep your mind off of it as much as possible.  You may even want to call your doctor and ask for a few day supply prescription for Xanax to help.
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 01:46PM Spoomsister wrote: Shirley, My doctor asked me if it would be okay for me to get the results via phone, and I said yes.  There wasn't a pathologist in the room to look at the cells, nor did they send them to pathology and wait.  It only took a couple of days for them to call me, but it was a LONG couple of days.  I really hope you find out it is B9.  Genny, I have my MRI on the 8th and my lymph node mapping is the night before surgery, on the 15th.  I can't believe I only have 13 days left with my boobs... I feel like I should be throwing a private Goodbye party or something.
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes
